Fields.DialogueText: Taking it easy today?
Rest is important when you train, Captain. Got to give those muscles a chance to rebuild.
With a glass of red wine and a sun reflector.
And the crossword in the Sunday Times.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't have thought you'd like this weather.
Doesn't this set a bad example for the crew?
Need any help?

Fields.DialogueText: Are we back to the vampire thing again? Why do you think I'm out here? The last time anyone spotted me with wine, I heard rumours about blood for a week.
They know I take play as seriously as I take work. I'll be running them twice as hard tomorrow.
I shouldn't. You'll be the first one I bother if I do.
You're welcome to join me if you'd like. We're not due to face the Morganas until...
Until?
Roughly now. I wondered why everyone seemed so flat out.
If I know you, Vampire, you're always ready for a fight.
Mine's a big gun, Captain, but it fits quite snugly under this deck chair.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Strewth. I was enjoying that wine.
I have to say the crew have never looked more fit.
I can't take all the credit. It takes two to train: one to train and one to be trained.
Not how I would have phrased it, but that makes sense.
There's the occasional bludger, but I've rotated through about my entire complement now. I think it's helped to see you training with me.

Fields.MenuText: I still don't know how that's going to work out. Their countries are still shooting at each other on land.
You sure it's not more Belle magic?
I imagine a lot of people sign up for the novelty.

Fields.DialogueText: Land's where the authorities are. Being out at sea puts things in perspective.
We're many things, Captain, but we are absolutely not magic. Besides, I'm not that bewitching.
The boot camps filter out most of the ones who've just come to gawk. You get the occasional nutter, but you find those everywhere.
It's certainly a good thing to cooperate the way we do. We need a good example of that these days.
Between you and me, it helps with the crossword too. I'm never far from someone with an answer to a clue I just don't get.
@BATTLE
I'm not a Belle. I'm just a person.
A person who a Belle trusts. Don't get me wrong, we're pretty amazing. But even with a human face to us... we're something other.
We're inspirational. But they look to you for leadership. I think that's why the international crews work so well together.
It's the little things that really show you how the world's changed, I guess.
Quite so, Captain. Oh, speaking of the crossword, I'm having the worst time trying to-
*ALARM*
Eight-letter word for "action stations?"
Morganas!
Ooh, this is whipping me right ropeable.
Still stuck on the Sunday crossword?
It's the hardest one, Captain. Especially this last bit over here. I'm still stuck on this clue from the other day.
Let's see... "Monster." That's it?
Vague like the plague.

Fields.MenuText: Have you tried the other clues that make it up?
You haven't asked the crew?
There has to be something more important going on.

Fields.DialogueText: I have, and it makes even less sense!
Where would I even begin? Every culture has monsters... and there's hundreds not represented among our crew.
I've been over every inch of my machinery to distract myself. No joy.
Let's see what you have here... "Vampyre?"
Number one, vampires aren't monsters. Number two, it's misspelled!
Sounds like something a vampire would say.
Yes! I mean no! I mean... grr. I'm writing the Times.
Does it really matter that much?
It does when you're trying to stay sharp. How can I beat a challenge that's not even right?
I thought this was your way of relaxing.
So did I.
*ALARM*
Well, at least I'm in the mood for these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Well, no luck so far.
Are you still on about the crossword?
I was. Everyone had different opinions about what else it might be, so I've just set it aside for now.

Fields.MenuText: What did you hear from the American crew?
Did your Japanese crew have any idea?
Are we sure it wasn't supposed to be a vampire?

Fields.DialogueText: Bigfoot, of course. Who else?
I've learned a lot about demons, but none of them seem to fit.
Positive.
Anyway, I've more important things to worry about. There's an ensign in the infirmary with the strangest illness...
What's wrong with them?
Anemia and fatigue, it looks like. He's looking rather pale and in and out of consciousness.
Keep an eye on him.
Round the clock, Captain. He's one of my best training partners.
He can keep up with you?
We've got some real speed demons serving aboard me, Captain. He's kept pace with me even at one-quarter speed.
So he's still leagues behind you.
Fair dinkum. I usually run sessions at one-eighth.
Looks like it's all ahead full, Vampire. Our ensign's in good hands.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Any improvement?
A bit, Captain. Steroids and antihistamines seem to be helping. Whatever it is was messing with his breathing.
It's not contagious, is it?
Doubtful, Captain, or we'd be seeing more crew with whatever it is he has.
Hmm. I'm glad you're keeping an eye on him. Some of these tropical diseases can be nasty.
All the more reason for the world to come together, I'd say. Who knows what kind of cures are locked away in your neighbour's cabinet?

Fields.MenuText: A lot of sickness spread from bringing the world closer together in the first place.
We're close to the Philippines. Do you think there might be a cure in port?
Nothing like a global threat to do it.

Fields.DialogueText: True enough, but there's only so much you can do to prevent something you've never seen.
I'll have the crew ask when they're there. In the meantime, advise them to wash their hands!
Whatever works, Captain. At the very least, the world should learn a lesson for the next one.
Let me know when he's fit to talk to us. We need to know exactly what happened to him.
Shouldn't be hard. These O boys are always robust.
O boys?
His blood type.
He hasn't needed a transfusion. How do you know his blood type?
Someone might, and you need to know who can help them if that happens. I know the blood type of everyone aboard. Yours too.
You're, um...
Say it. Out loud.
Helpful! I was going to say helpful! A lot of Belles wouldn't bother memorizing... blood types.
Just things you pick up over a long service history.
*ALARM*
Right, enough foolishness. Let's have a Captain Cook at some real monsters.
@BATTLE
You've been out and about lately.
Taking in the sun, Captain. Lots of it.
I said I was sorry about the vampire thing. It's just-
Ahh, no drama, Captain. I know you don't mean any harm. Besides, our little blood feud got me thinking. Ever read the ghost stories here in the Philippines?
There are some distinctly vampiric figures, right?
Too right! Every culture has `em. Here in this part of the world they call them aswangs.
You think that might be what's wrong with the ensign?
No such thing as monsters, Captain. But every myth has an origin. We need to get to the bottom of this one.

Fields.MenuText: You don't believe in them?
You're doing enough in the infirmary. We don't need to chase ghost stories.
What could possibly explain his symptoms?

Fields.DialogueText: Just because we've got ghost ships about doesn't mean there's other supernatural nasties.
It's the one thing we haven't done, Captain. We can let this burn out or we can take a gamble on ending it.
I'm no doctor, but it might have been an allergic reaction. If nobody else shows symptoms, the problem's on his end.
I don't know how I feel about entertaining superstitions. Not when there's a rational explanation staring us in the face.
Deadset. But a little protection can improve the mood. It might put the crew's minds at ease. Some of them are starting to talk.
Well, we should put a stop to it. There's more important things to worry about.
Superstition's like disease, Captain. You can aggressively treat it or let it run its course.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, let's go down your ridiculous checklist.
You helped make it, Captain. You're complicit.
Don't I know it. Let's see... red armbands.
Distributed to all crew. Aswangs don't like red. Reminds them of fire.
Well, obviously. Garlic.
I notice this involves a lot of decoration and snacks.
It's all about warding the environment against spirits! A little decoration goes a long way.
Positive externalities. Let's see... looks like we've been over the rest. Anything we're missing?
Whoa! Back up, Vampire.
Ha, good. Sorry, Captain. I had to look real close. Aswang eyes reflect upside down.
Oh, for goodness's sake.
It may seem batty, and that's because it is. But if it sets the crew's mind at ease, I'll take it.

Fields.MenuText: It honestly makes me feel better.
Heh. Batty.
If we start burning witches, you're to blame.

Fields.DialogueText: When you're dealing with the intangible, the perception of doing something is as good as gold.
That was a test, Captain. You failed.
Plenty of water about to test whether they float, though.
I can't believe we're entertaining this nonsense.
Superstitions have their place, Captain. They fill in the blanks in people's understanding. As long as nobody's hurt, where's the harm?
About at the point where people start getting staked and beheaded.
Lucky you've got me around. My sisters are even more superstitious than I am.
I guess vampires are a little less scary if you look like one.
@BATTLE
Appropriated from the galley and hung round the perimeter of the deck.
... Though I admit I'll be keeping the garlic to myself.
Hold still.
There's a lot in a name. Poor Valorous can't let down her guard for a minute, or everyone will think she's losing her grip.
If she's anything like you, she never will.
You're a true mate, Captain. I'm glad you're on my side.
*ALARM*
Shame that garlic doesn't work on Morganas.
I hope you brought firewood, Captain.
It is absolutely not that cold.
Easy for you to say! You're not used to the waters of the Mediterranean.
Will some tea help?
Ceylon and blood orange?

Fields.MenuText: Now you're just messing with me.
Please don't.
It pairs pretty well with swordfish.

Fields.DialogueText: That's how you know you're in my good books.
Just an expression, Captain. Be proud.
I'll take your word for it.
Seen any aswangs?
I would have raised the alarm and gotten you in on the fight if I had.
How nice of you to include me in your battles with the supernatural.
We can't do it alone.
Not to hear some of the other Belles tell it.
@BATTLE
What else?
Thanks, friend. Your blood's worth bottling.
I love my sisters, don't get me wrong... but Achilles can be a right bloody show pony. Comes with the name, I expect. Just look at Valorous.
A name can put a lot of pressure on a person. Imagine how HMS Victory must have felt.
The thought had crossed my mind. It takes a little longer sometimes. But that's just how sisters are.
*ALARM*
Looks like a shot's crossed your bow.
Well, if the tea hadn't warmed us up, this would. Thanks, Captain. I needed this.

Fields.MenuText: Fair point.
Oh, yes, I am. With skin, I might add, not steel.

Fields.DialogueText: Fine. But you're not in the water now!
Our patient's out and about.
You were with him. Wasn't he in critical condition?
I wish these Morganas would rack off.
@BATTLE
Did we find out what was causing the sickness?
It's a mystery, Captain. I guess a little bed rest was all he needed.
That puts paid to all the vampire rumours. Or aswang rumours, whichever.
Does it?

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean?
I just want people to move on.
You've been reading too many of your books.

Fields.DialogueText: Call it a hunch, Captain, or just paranoia.
Out at sea sailors make their own excitement. It might take another scare for this to blow over.
Oh, don't be such an ocker.
It's just not right, Captain. I'm glad he's on his feet, but it feels... anticlimactic. I should have done more.
I remember Valhalla telling me something before we... back in the old days. She always got nervous when things got quiet.
Let me guess. Too quiet?
Up until the shooting started.
Never critical, but dodgy all the same. Sometimes these things just rack off like that.
You watched a sick man like a hawk. Anyone would be lucky to get the kind of treatment you gave.
Bit morbid.
Always had one foot in the afterlife, did my dear sister...
What's this nonsense I hear about a fight?
I had to break it up personally. It was me and our recovered friend against two of-
The radio crew.
Gosh, how'd you guess?
I love my crew, Captain... but some of those boys are a bit funny.

Fields.MenuText: Think we need to replace them?
Looks like another few late nights for you.
Where does Command find these people?

Fields.DialogueText: We need their expertise for now, but I'm certainly exploring my options.
Anything that keeps me below decks of a chilly evening.
I'm penning a letter about superstition screening myself. There's a difference between red sky at night and vampires.
I was in the mess when it happened. Someone made a smart remark about the ensign's quick recovery and the vampire watching over him.
I didn't think people actually did that.
Seems we're learning a lot about each other. Things went downhill from there.
You're not wrong. But I didn't sign up for this nonsense. We know who our enemy is.
Then someone else stood up and slapped him with a glove.
It's a good thing you've been training with me, eh, Captain?
Valentine used to talk about her submarine hunts in the North Sea. Imagine being surrounded by an unseen enemy. When is it too late to let your depth charges go and hope for the best?
You're not seriously defending the radiomen.
No, they're a couple of bloody dipsticks. But the less understanding you have, the easier it is to feel cornered.
*ALARM*
If you've got an idea for teaching the crew mythology, it's going to have to wait.
I might. And I might not. As with the Morganas, some things we just have to be ready for.
@BATTLE
Just in time. I was getting a chill even down here.
I've heard vampires have low body temperatures.
Don't make me drain you dry.
How's the shift coming?
How's the... hearing?
Fine.
Have you ever known you were missing something right in front of you and not known how to look for it?

Fields.MenuText: You're still thinking about your sisters?
Sometimes. These things are always in the last place I look.
I feel like you've read me a story very much like this.

Fields.DialogueText: Come to think of it, Captain... yes, I have.
Well, obviously. You stop looking afterward.
Oh, I'm always thinking about them. But my mind's closer to home right now.
One of the Norse myths was on my mind. The one where Baldr's mother talked to everything in the world to forbid it from hurting him.
I feel like we're just waiting for it right now.
We're doing all we can. I've given the belligerents a full dressing down while they recover. They'll be back on duty tomorrow, and on a much shorter leash.
Thank you. Maybe now they'll learn not to accuse their fellow crew of bloody vampirism.
Tea for you.
Doing the best with what we have. I don't have quite the range of the newer girls back in the old country.
Except the mistletoe.
We'll just have to get some werewolves on board to set their minds at ease.
Oh, can we, Captain? I've always wanted some pets to run with.
As long as you feed them and clean up after them.
*ALARM*
Belay that, Captain. Looks like we've all got some cleanup to do.
@BATTLE
Room for one more runner?
Always, Captain! I've been short on partners lately. And I need to talk to you anyway.
One would think the radio crew would be jumping at the chance to test themselves against you.
They've been wisely steering clear of me.
Or at least Ensign Lee.
He's been making excuses lately.
I'd probably be watching my health too after what happened to him.
He's earned the right. It's urgent, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Think we'll need to replace the radiomen?
Who is it this time?
What would anyone have against him?

Fields.DialogueText: They're a mob of hoons, but they're not dangerous. Bloody nuisance, but an even bloodier nuisance to replace them. We need their expertise. But enough about them. Lee's in danger.
One of the cooks. I'm going to find out which.
Not him specifically. He got caught in the crossfire of something deeply stupid.
What on earth does this have to do with Lee?
I wasn't sure at first, either. Which is why I read his journal while he was on shift.
First of all, I'm grinning like a shot fox that I appropriated all the garlic-
*ALARM*
Damn. I'll tell you later. You're not going to like this.
@BATTLE
You what?
Don't look so scandalised. I've been around long enough to act when I know those I trust are threatened.
That's the last we'll see of that cook.
And just in time for dinner.
I still can't believe someone would dose the food with garlic to try and expose you as a vampire.
Or anyone else I'd turned. Or, you know, anyone who happened to be allergic to garlic. Lee's luckier than he knows that I was watching over him.

Fields.MenuText: We can't defend our crew from our crew.
Forget vampires. It's people that are dangerous.
You don't think they would have tried to finish the job?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be so sure. I've gone my whole life without throwing anyone overboard, but there's a first time for everything.
I'll still take a couple of poisonous whackers over the Morganas.
People can do terrible things to those they don't consider people.
Well, I'm ordering the garlic be taken down. All the red armbands can come off the uniforms, too.
Agreed, Captain. The more we cater to the vampire myth, the more we encourage every mad dill with a stake to take matters into their own hands.
Some of the crew might not like it, but they'll out themselves soon enough.
We'll just have to be ready when they do.
When you awoke, did you ever think you'd be fighting people?
I'm not the first Belle to ask that question of herself. I certainly won't be the last.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
But I think I'm the only one that's had to deal with an answer this bloody moronic.
I don't want to step on your toes, Vampire-
Stow it.
So you know what I'm talking about. We've all heard it.
Screaming and flapping in the night, Captain? Really?
It sounds crazy to me too. I wouldn't even pay attention if I hadn't heard it too.
We're playing with fire here, Captain. It's already burned Ensign Lee.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think there might be something unexplained going on?
We solved that problem already.
So we just let these things go on?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think we need to chase any more ghosts than we're already chasing!
No, Captain, we haven't, and I'm beginning to think we might never.
If they don't pose a danger to the crew, yes.
Look, it's not just the noises. We've got two crew in the infirmary with cuts and scratches, and not from the Morganas.
Two crew who were on night watch when they - and the rest of us - heard the sounds.
We're in the middle of the ocean and you're looking for blooming vampires! Do you have any idea how mad you sound?
Yes. What's mad is that whatever we were trying to stop didn't end with the cook.
And I suppose it's just a coincidence that this all started up again after I took the garlic down.
Of course not. I'm not saying we missed a secret vampire, Vampire. I'm saying that there are people aboard convinced that we did.
Save your vampire story for the lakeside retreat, Polidori. I'm going to go fight some real monsters.
@BATTLE
So they tripped. They'll be right.
*ALARM*
You're welcome.
What's this?
Everything I could track down on the vampire problem. Some Filipino grandmothers in port got talkative.
What in God's name is a wakwak?
Like an aswang, but more like a bird. It matched what people were saying about the flapping noises, not to mention the lacerations.
Excellent research, Vampire.
You might say it's my specialty.

Fields.MenuText: No, I might not.
I'm sorry. I know this isn't fair to you.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, come now, Captain. My sense of humour hasn't completely racked off.
No, Captain, I'm sorry.
You can laugh. That was intended to be a joke.
Listen... I know you're only trying to run a tight ship under pressure. And whatever's happening to our crew, it's got nothing to do with me but that I'm their Belle. I need to act like it.
It's not enough for some of them. You said it yourself, Captain. Someone aboard is convinced we missed a vampire or two.
I didn't have anything to do with-
... A vampire's thrall in a captain's uniform.
@BATTLE
You're already going above and beyond for the crew.
And now the radiomen have been cowed, the cook's gone, and the watch are injured. All of which we had something to do with.
Who set the watch schedule?
Now you understand where I'm coming from. If we don't solve this mystery, some other mongrel will. With stakes this time instead of garlic.
*ALARM*
Looks like we're going vampire hunter hunting.
I guess that makes the Morganas vampire hunter hunter hunters.
Ha ha. Suck down a blood bag and let's get moving.
Brr. Too right. I'm within cooee of building a campfire.
No, I mean waiting around for the wakwak is ridiculous. Or whatever it's supposed to be.
Only if you expect to find one.

Fields.MenuText: You don't?
What would we do if we did?
I don't know what I expect anymore.

Fields.DialogueText: That is not what "expect the unexpected" means, and you know it.
They're powerful, but I don't think they've got magic to stop a Lewis gun.
Expectations can trip you up if you let them, Captain.
I don't know how they even expect to fight you the way they'd fight a vampire.
When you spend your whole life planning for nothing, you become the hero of your own story. The only thing sadder is if you plan to fail.
Well, sunlight demonstrably doesn't harm you. Neither does garlic. I doubt a stake would so much as scratch you.
This is ridiculous.
Vampire myths vary from culture to culture, and strong vampires usually have fewer of the weaknesses of the common ones.
The storytellers really did think of everything over the years.
It's nothing to do with human stories, Captain. People can adapt their madness to all sorts of inconvenient truths. They're cunning as a dunny rat about it.
Wait. Do you hear that?
Flapping, and... odd, that sounds like--
Stop right there! This is your captain speaking!
Gah!
It's her! Everyone for themselves!
Oh, give it a rest, you mug.
What the hell were you two doing with the canvas and knives?
T-training, Captain, for when--
*ALARM*
This is what you should be training for. Vampire, get them to the brig.
No, please, anything but her--
Why, yes, Captain!
@BATTLE
What did we find?
So they actually thought they could destroy you. And they were willing to fake vampire attacks to build support for their hunt for a real one.
It's not me I'm worried about, Captain. It's anyone else aboard me who might look a little too pale and sleep-deprived.

Fields.MenuText: They wouldn't have.

Fields.DialogueText: The longer they saw our stubborn refusal to recognize the vampire problem, the likelier it would have been.

Fields.MenuText: Or me, for being your thrall.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't need to dominate you to get you to go along with my plans.

Fields.MenuText: Ensign Lee.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I would have loved to see them go for him. He could fold one of those dills exactly in half.
Not to mention petty theft. They'd had rice and beans from the galley squirreled away with the stakes.
What on earth could they want with that?
Hadn't you read, Captain? Vampires are obsessed with counting.
Well, we can rest assured they're going back to their countries. Conspiracy to commit murder should keep them off the seas for life.
Well, the Bibles aren't odd in and of themselves. Stuffed in mattresses with sharpened stakes, they take on a different meaning.
So if you'd come after them, their plan was to scatter rice in your path and hope for the best. Where did they train, a wedding?
Not really the full quid, were they? I might trip and get seven thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight grains of rice in my hair, but that's about it.
Well, I'll draft a letter to Command. On behalf of my crew, I humbly apologize. You're dismissed.
Thank you, Captain.
... Wait. How do you know how many-
*ALARM*
Come off it. If you haven't a sense of humour, you haven't anything. General quarters, then?
@BATTLE
Must you do your runs at the hottest part of the day?
I can only run so fast before the mob get discouraged.
Pretty day out, though.
What's this about, Captain?
You've been running alone lately.
I've trained them well enough. There's nothing more they can learn from me.

Fields.MenuText: You could make them run with weights.
Not even to keep them sharp?
Isolating yourself isn't going to help.

Fields.DialogueText: That wouldn't be sporting for a predator, would it?
They're right corkers at sharpening things already.
I can appear wherever I like. I'm not isolated.
You know, sometimes I wish I really was a vampire.
Don't be ridiculous. You'd burst into flames on a day like today.
It takes more than a little sun to off the powerful ones, Captain. And even if not, who's to say I couldn't make my own clouds like a Morgana?
Not to mention the immortality.
Wouldn't that be useful?
Wait, Vampire, slow down!
We've got monsters inbound, Captain. You keep up.
@BATTLE
Dispatch from Command, Captain?
Behold the most sarcastic letter the higher-ups have ever had to write.
"With the obvious exception of the Morganas, the existence of vampires, ghosts, demons, etc. is currently unconfirmed by the central command structure of the INPF and its constituent bodies..."
"... therefore no action in opposition to such creatures, corporeal or otherwise, is recommended or necessary. Any unilateral action is to be dealt with as reasonable commanders see fit."
I'm embarrassed that this was even necessary.
Are you having me on, Captain? We should have this framed and hung in the mess.

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully this is the end of this.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I should have leaned into the vampire thing.
From the way those crew were talking about you, I thought you had.
You'd better hope there's no such thing as jinxes, either.

Fields.MenuText: They'll be laughing about this for weeks back in Zurich.
The less I have to think about this nonsense, the better.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. We need a little ridicule to keep us honest.
That's because you're not a complete berk.
Do I look scary to you, Captain?
You look like you. I know who you are. I work with you. You're my friend.
That's what I thought about my training partners. All it took was one rumour to change the way they saw me.
You know, it's been a while since we sparred last. Maybe a little civilised knockaround will jog their memory.
*ALARM*
It might at that. They can't avoid me forever. And I can't avoid them.
Now let's show them we're in their corner.
@BATTLE
All right, are we ready?
Ready!
Ready.

Fields.MenuText: Last out of the ring is the winner!
Keep your fists high and your knees low!
Ten enter, one leaves!

Fields.DialogueText: Fists up, ensigns. Don't give me a bodgy battle now.
And say your prayers. It might set your minds at ease.
And all learn from the experience. Hopefully.
Begin!
Whoa! What? Time out!
What's wrong?
You. Ensign. What do you have there?
... Knuckledusters, Miss.
Made of?
Silver.
That's exactly what I thought they were. Stand still.
Gah!
Vampire! Get him back aboard this instant!
That's the plan. Back in a tick.
All right, Poseidon. Next time you bail someone up, use the proper tool. Silver's for werewolves, you great lurking galah.
That goes for the rest of you! Read the manifests. You won't find blood bags in my budget. If I were a real vampire I'd have drained you all dry and there would have been nothing you could have done!
Now rack off to action stations! All of you! There's real monsters to slay, and I know I trained you well enough to slay them!
@BATTLE
Hah!
Think they got the message?
Plenty of ocean about if they didn't.
Need a pick-me-up?
I'll give it a fair go, Captain. Thank you.
Here. I brought you a roasted garlic bulb and some nice red wine.
Well... that does sound really nice right now.
Why don't you sit down for a little bit? You've been working yourself pretty hard recently.
Standard operating procedure when I spit the dummy. I'm trying to work through everything that's happened. That's still happening, I reckon.

Fields.MenuText: Spit the dummy?
You dealt with it pretty well, all things considered.
Do you need some time alone?

Fields.DialogueText: Get ropeable. Spewing. Cranky. Mad as a cut snake. You'll pick up my lingo with time.
Some things you can't get just by asking.
I've felt alone for long enough.
I've seen some of the crew apologizing.
When Ensign Lee started running with me again, I think that's what turned it around. Though the whole knuckleduster bizzo certainly made an impact.
You never really know what will change the way someone looks at you.
I can guess. Did you know my name wasn't always Vampire?
What was it?
Wallace. For all of a month.
Snrk. Sorry, it just sounds-
After William Wallace. Hammer of the English and defender of Scottish independence.
Ah. That Wallace. Yes, that sounds considerably more-
Heroic. Inspiring. Friendlier, at the very least, than Vampire.
Hey, enough of this. We're invincible out here thanks to you. And I wouldn't trade you for any Belle in the fleet.
You're a good friend, Captain. Sometimes I just get to wondering what I'd look like if I'd stayed Wallace. Who I'd be. How people would receive me.
People like to think they're above appearances and they're not, Captain. No one is.
That's our curse. What matters is that we let ourselves look beyond those appearances. The world's a lot scarier if we don't.
Scarier than these Morganas?
*ALARM*
By a country mile.
@BATTLE
Did you ever get word from the Times about your puzzle?
Blimey, I'd almost forgotten about it.
So that's a no.
It's one of those things you don't really miss until you remember you wanted it.

Fields.MenuText: That's unfortunate. I know how worked up you were over it.
Like garlic.
I'm surprised I even remembered.

Fields.DialogueText: It's almost embarrassing now I look back on it.
Oh, I missed it, all right. Hanging it round the deck instead of roasting it felt like using steak for wallpaper.
I'm not the only one who appreciates a proper challenge.
I wonder if that's where this whole jug of fish started.
I was venting to the crew about it during our runs. I think something about "Vampires aren't monsters" might have touched a nerve with some of them.
You can't blame yourself for that. There's no answering for the things that set off people's delusions.
There's the obvious things, Captain. You'll notice I haven't been hanging upside down lately.
Maybe that's why you've been slowing in our runs. You're used to a rush of blood to the head now and again.
Drongo.
Nosferatu.
What do you mean?
Dunny budgie.
Leech.
*ALARM*
Come on, Captain. I'm feeling some upside-down trick shots after all.
@BATTLE
Ha! I win!
Win what?
Letter from the Times, Captain. Read it.
"... error in the crossword dated Sunday the... Clue should have been 'John Polidori's monster,' not 'monster.'"
You a big reader, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I've read what you recommended me.
Polidori... the name rings a bell.
Voracious.

Fields.DialogueText: Clearly your education's incomplete!
It should. I clubbed you with it the other day.
Liar! I can't believe you didn't see it before.
Back before Dracula, one John Polidori wrote a little book called The Vampyre. With a Y.
Oh, dry up, Captain. Sometimes you've got to trust your first instinct, and I sure as hell didn't.
Is it a good book, at least?
Depends on what you're looking for in a vampire story. It's not the happiest of endings, but the twist always gets me wobbly.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
What was that about judging by appearance?
I'll have to find out for myself. We've got some staking to do.
Back on the job, I see.
I told the radiomen to take a break. Thought a bit of charity might rebuild the bridge they dismantled and made stakes of.
So to speak.
And then this shift turned out to be a right boring load of yakka. Sacrifices, Captain. But the wine helps, at least.

Fields.MenuText: Drinking on the job?
I'm glad you're making amends. It's magnanimous of you.
Back to the crosswords, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be such a wowser. I know you better than that. It keeps me sharp and I know my limits.
They apologised first. Even I was surprised.
That broken one was a fluke, thank goodness.
You know, there's something still bothering me, if you've got the time to discuss it.
The floor's yours.
What you said about the manifests... I was going over them the other day just for accounting's sake.
And I thought this job was boring.
Well, it's as you say. Everyone's personal expenses are clean. But the general requisitions... Do we really need that much blood in the infirmary?
When you've fought the battles I have, you learn a little extra never hurts.
I'll take your word for it. Medicine's not my field.
Nor mine. But it has its uses.
*ALARM*
Better polish this glass off. Unless you'd like to help me finish it?
I think I'll pass.
@BATTLE.
That's going to be the last of the Philippines. Enjoy it while you can.
@BATTLE
Look at the clouds, Captain! Nothing better than a glass of red wine and a storm.
It's certainly ominous. You don't get storms like these on the mainland.
Prime weather for a santilmo.
You mean St. Elmo's fire?
Pretty much. That's just what the Filipinos call it. Fire spirits that appear when blood is spilled.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we'll finally see something supernatural on this tour.
What do we do if we see one?
So ball lightning.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, there's a rational explanation for everything. But it's a spiffy story all the same.
Stay out of the way. It won't harm us if we don't bother it.
Even that's not been explained. Isn't it exciting to speculate?
I guess that's not a bad story.
It's what stories are for, Captain. They fill in the blanks where we don't understand things. You've just got to be willing to put them on the shelf once you learn the truth.
I'll try, Captain. These Morganas are bound and determined to bodge it up!
Good thing you like a fight.
It's what I'm made for, Captain!
Well, I'm not shelving you any time soon. Your story's still being written.
And yours.
Bugger me! Damn wind. Clumsy, clumsy, clumsy...
Whoa! Watch where you're spilling that wine!
Oh, look, Captain! Out on the water! See the lights?
... What?
Vampire... what did you say about the santilmo just now?
Oh, silly Captain. We both know there's no such thing as monsters. Don't we?
